Well, whatever. But what about some good old nuances?

I played this game on two different platforms, and my experience with it stayed the same. [u]I do believe this is one of the most na√Øve games when it comes to executing the concept of new bioethics, robotics, and futuristic realism. At parts, this game wants to be ‚ÄòNever Let Me Go‚Äô from Kazuo Ishiguro, but ends up being Another Product from David Cage who loves his bingo card tropes way too much[/u]. That‚Äôs how we meet:

‚õîÔ∏è1) Incredibly obtuse and dense plot moments that are forcing you to feel the way intended by Cage, or otherwise you‚Äôd be ‚Äòexperiencing Detroit not properly‚Äô. [u]They really are manipulative in a way that a player doesn‚Äôt get recognized as a smart creature capable of processing more nuanced and complex thoughts by the game[/u]. Cage really wants to put everything in your face, and sometimes characters literally instruct you how to feel ([i]Alice reveal and Luther‚Äôs words about it are really the worst part of the entire game, it was almost laughable[/i]). 

‚õîÔ∏è2) Markus‚Äôs plot ark is one of the worst ‚Äòrebel arks‚Äô I‚Äôve seen, especially in the context of android rhetoric ‚Äì plot-wise, script-wise and ideology wise, but so much deeper and better stuff had already been said about it by other people, I won‚Äôt be repeating much about it here. There‚Äôs a reason this is objectively the least liked part of the entire game for the majority of players, and some of its parts are so linear but also drag for so long, it gets insufferable during re-plays. 

‚õîÔ∏è3) David Cage‚Äôs ego made the overall game‚Äôs impact much cheaper due to his direct and damaging involvement in the script. [u]Thus the infamous DC bingo cards‚Äô moments travelling into every single game of Quantic Dream (no literally, look them up, they are hilarious)[/u], Kara‚Äôs plot line, amazing in its concept but almost destroyed by some of the decisions taken later into the game‚Äôs production, and so much more.

Please watch this movie, it‚Äôs so silly, but it still adapted the major concepts of robotics and new life ethics so much better than this entire game‚Ä¶ Also, David Cage clearly wanted to give Hank same exact motivation to hate the androids as Will Smith does, but they were forced to change it in a ridiculous way just to avoid plagiarism allegations, aaand now the Hank motif doesn‚Äôt even make any sense‚Ä¶

[u]The amount of work live actors did during every take, every voice line recording and every action sequence filming, is astonishing. Detroit: Become Human is not just a game ‚Äì it‚Äôs an experience.
Quantic Dream created a powerful interactive story where every decision truly matters and where the player is constantly faced with one big question: "What does it mean to be human?"

The game follows three main characters ‚Äì Connor, Markus, and Kara ‚Äì each offering a different perspective on a world where androids begin to gain their own thoughts, emotions, and desires. It‚Äôs fascinating to watch their stories unfold and see how even a small choice can snowball into major consequences.

And that‚Äôs the beauty of Detroit: Become Human ‚Äì you control their fate. There is no single ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù path. Instead, there are dozens of endings ranging from victory and hope to sacrifice, tragedy, or quiet defeat caused by just one wrong decision.

The graphics and motion capture are stunning ‚Äì Detroit feels alive, believable, and deeply atmospheric. The emotional expressions on characters‚Äô faces are some of the best in gaming, and the soundtrack enhances every scene perfectly, from high tension to heartbreak.

Each protagonist is memorable:
- Connor deals with the struggle between cold professionalism and growing humanity,
- Kara delivers a touching personal story of care and protection,
- Markus represents the bigger picture ‚Äì the fight for identity and freedom.

Detroit: Become Human is the kind of game that stays with you long after the credits roll. It makes you think, doubt yourself, feel, lose, win ‚Äì and most importantly, it makes you want to play again, because there is always another path, another ending, another possibility.

For me ‚Äì an emotional and unforgettable story-driven masterpiece that anyone who loves strong narrative games, meaningful choices, and deep characters should experience.

With the ascent of artificial intelligence, the world portrayed in Detroit is becoming increasingly palpable. More and more individuals find themselves imperiled, at risk of losing their occupations, and, by extension, their very sense of identity, to unfeeling machines. Contemplating whether this outcome is genuinely imminent feels essential if we wish to progress coherently as a society.

This is precisely where Detroit excels. The game interrogates the very nature of androids: whether they merit being regarded as living beings or whether they are merely intricate automatons and nothing more. It explores their potential impact on our civilization and on what we may eventually become.

The work guides you through a gameplay experience that is understated yet profoundly narrative-driven, urging you to forge your own judgement and perspective. It compels you to scrutinize your decisions, while its performances, staging, visuals, and music into a singular piece of artistry. Together, they invite us to discern what may await us in the future and what precautions we ought to adopt.

I simply feel it is not merely a game you should play, rather an introspective examination of what we, as a society, are in the midst of creating.

The only eye-watering aspect of this game is the atrociously exaggerated depth of field (DOF) graphics effect, which puts 99% of the screen out of focus.
Apparently this is specific to the PC version and cannot be turned off in-game.
Of course, the developers have never bothered to fix this in five years, so you have to do it yourself:

You have to replace a value in the game's EXE file with a HEX editor, for example via the hexedit plug-in in Notepad++ (free, I think open-souce).
[h3]Search Reddit for the thread "/r/DetroitBecomeHuman/comments/ejpbnu/any_fix_for_the_terrible_blur/" if you want more info, or just do this:
1. Open <path-to-game>\DetroitBecomeHuman.exe in a hex editor.
2. Search for 
"41 C7 83 40 01 00 00 31 00 00" as hex.
3. Replace it with 
"7F C7 83 40 01 00 00 31 00 00" aka just replace the leading "41" with "7F".
4. Save and close.
5. Play D:BH without getting eye cancer.[/h3]

[h3]FIX for the DOF effect:[/h3]
The only eye-watering aspect of this game is the atrociously exaggerated depth of field (DOF) graphics effect, which puts 99% of the screen out of focus.
Apparently this is specific to the PC version and cannot be turned off in-game.
Of course, the developers have never bothered to fix this in five years, so you have to do it yourself:

You have to replace a value in the game's EXE file with a HEX editor, for example via the hexedit plug-in in Notepad++ (free, I think open-souce).
[h3]Search Reddit for the thread "/r/DetroitBecomeHuman/comments/ejpbnu/any_fix_for_the_terrible_blur/" if you want more info, or just do this:
1. Open <path-to-game>\DetroitBecomeHuman.exe in a hex editor.
2. Search for 
"41 C7 83 40 01 00 00 31 00 00" as hex.
3. Replace it with 
"7F C7 83 40 01 00 00 31 00 00" aka just replace the leading "41" with "7F".
4. Save and close.
5. Play D:BH without getting eye cancer.[/h3]

The core idea of the story and the moral premise is what makes it interesting, but as the conclusion of the game gets nearer, all nuance is stripped away and it kind of forces you into a certain ending. Overall, its not a bad game, but its pretty overrated in my opinion, and not worth the time.
